DataElement.preferredName: Isolated Limb Perfusion Infusion Procedure Tourniquet Identifier
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Identifier to distinguish between more than one tourniquets used during in isolated limb perfusion (ILP) or isolated limb infusion (ILI) procedure.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Isolated Limb Perfusion Infusion Procedure Tourniquet Identification
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A procedure used to deliver anticancer drugs directly to an arm or leg but not to the rest of the body. The flow of blood to and from the limb is temporarily stopped with a tourniquet (a tight band around the limb). Catheters (small, flexible tubes) attached to a pump are put into an artery and a vein in the limb so that blood can be circulated through the pump into the limb. Anticancer drugs are injected into the catheters. Wrapping the limb in a heated blanket or warming the drugs or blood may help the drugs work better._A method of putting fluids, including drugs, into the bloodstream._A device, such as a strip of cloth or a band of rubber, that is wrapped tightly around a leg or an arm to prevent the flow of blood to the leg or the arm for a period of time. A tourniquet may be used when drawing blood or to stop bleeding after an injury._The procedure of having an identity established.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Isolated Chemotherapeutic Limb Perfusion Infusion Procedure Tourniquet
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A procedure used to deliver anticancer drugs directly to an arm or leg but not to the rest of the body. The flow of blood to and from the limb is temporarily stopped with a tourniquet (a tight band around the limb). Catheters (small, flexible tubes) attached to a pump are put into an artery and a vein in the limb so that blood can be circulated through the pump into the limb. Anticancer drugs are injected into the catheters. Wrapping the limb in a heated blanket or warming the drugs or blood may help the drugs work better.:A method of putting fluids, including drugs, into the bloodstream.:A device, such as a strip of cloth or a band of rubber, that is wrapped tightly around a leg or an arm to prevent the flow of blood to the leg or the arm for a period of time. A tourniquet may be used when drawing blood or to stop bleeding after an injury.

Concepts.definition: A procedure used to deliver anticancer drugs directly to an arm or leg but not to the rest of the body. The flow of blood to and from the limb is temporarily stopped with a tourniquet (a tight band around the limb). Catheters (small, flexible tubes) attached to a pump are put into an artery and a vein in the limb so that blood can be circulated through the pump into the limb. Anticancer drugs are injected into the catheters. Wrapping the limb in a heated blanket or warming the drugs or blood may help the drugs work better.
Any form of treatment that is introduced into the body via a blood vessel, a muscle, or the spinal cord.

A device, such as a strip of cloth or a band of rubber, that is wrapped tightly around a leg or an arm to prevent the flow of blood to the leg or the arm for a period of time. A tourniquet may be used when drawing blood or to stop bleeding after an injury.

Property.preferredDefinition: Identified; having the identity known or established.

Concepts.definition: The procedure of having an identity established.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: A practiced and regimented skill or series of actions.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.
